source_methodology: Evidence-based progressions from rehabilitation and sports science textbooks
strength_calculations: Based on biomechanical analysis and EMG research

relationships.source_research: Escamilla et al. (2001): Knee biomechanics during squatting variations
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Box reduces range of motion to pain-free range while maintaining squat motor pattern. Reduces patellofemoral contact pressure by 35% compared to deep squats.
relationships.clinical_application: Knee pain, hip mobility limitations, learning squat mechanics
relationships.notes: Box height individualized to pain-free range of motion
relationships.progression_criteria: Pain-free completion for 2+ weeks before advancing

relationships.source_research: Swinton et al. (2011): Comparison of deadlift variations
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Neutral grip and elevated handles reduce spine flexion moment by 25%. More upright torso position reduces lumbar stress while maintaining posterior chain activation.
relationships.clinical_application: Lower back pain, grip strength limitations, learning deadlift mechanics
relationships.notes: Often allows higher loads due to improved mechanics and reduced range of motion
relationships.equipment_modification: Trap bar with high handles optimal for beginners

relationships.source_research: Signorile et al. (2002): EMG comparison of vertical pulling exercises
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Machine-assisted version allows load titration. Maintains similar muscle activation patterns (lat dorsi 85% of pull-up levels) while removing bodyweight limitation.
relationships.clinical_application: Insufficient relative strength for bodyweight pull-ups, shoulder limitations
relationships.notes: Maintain pull-up grip width and tempo to optimize transfer

relationships.source_research: Fees et al. (1998): Upper extremity modifications for injured athletes
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Diagonal pressing plane reduces shoulder impingement risk by 60%. Natural scapular movement allowed throughout range of motion.
relationships.clinical_application: Shoulder impingement, rotator cuff irritation, limited overhead mobility
relationships.movement_analysis: Arc of motion follows natural scapulohumeral rhythm, reducing subacromial compression
relationships.notes: Can be performed unilaterally to address asymmetries
relationships.progression: Gradually increase pressing angle toward vertical as mobility improves

relationships.source_research: Myer et al. (2014): Movement screen and squat assessment in youth athletes
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Front-loading naturally promotes upright torso and teaches proper squat mechanics. Counterbalance effect reduces balance demands by 40%.
relationships.clinical_application: Learning squat patterns, ankle mobility restrictions, balance deficits

teaching_progression.week_1_2: Bodyweight goblet squat, focus on depth
teaching_progression.week_3_4: Light load (10-20 lbs), improve range of motion
teaching_progression.week_5_6: Moderate load (25-40 lbs), add tempo control
teaching_progression.week_7_8: Transition to front squat or back squat

relationships.mobility_requirements: Ankle dorsiflexion >15°, hip flexion >110°, thoracic extension >20°

relationships.source_research: Calatayud et al. (2015): Muscle activation during push-up variations
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Incline reduces percentage of body weight lifted. 30° incline = 65% body weight, 45° incline = 55% body weight vs 75% for standard push-up.
relationships.clinical_application: Insufficient upper body strength, wrist pain, learning push-up mechanics
relationships.notes: Maintain plank position throughout entire range of motion

relationships.source_research: Boudreau et al. (2009): EMG analysis of lunge variations
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Reverse stepping pattern reduces anterior knee forces by 20%. Easier balance control as weight shifts to stable base leg.
relationships.clinical_application: Anterior knee pain, balance deficits, learning lunge mechanics
relationships.notes: Preferred variation for individuals with patellofemoral pain syndrome

relationships.source_research: McAllister et al. (2014): Muscle activation during deadlift variations
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Reduced range of motion emphasizes eccentric control and hamstring flexibility. 40% greater hamstring activation vs conventional deadlift.
relationships.clinical_application: Hamstring development, learning hip hinge pattern, mobility emphasis
relationships.movement_pattern: Top-down movement starting from standing position, bar travels to mid-shin level
relationships.notes: Excellent for developing hamstring strength and hip hinge mechanics before progressing to full deadlift

relationships.source_research: Lehman et al. (2004): Effect of trunk position on rowing exercise
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Chest support eliminates erector spinae demand, reducing spinal compression forces by 60%. Allows focus on targeted back muscles without trunk stability limitations.
relationships.clinical_application: Lower back pain, poor trunk endurance, learning rowing mechanics
relationships.notes: Preferred during acute lower back pain episodes

relationships.source_research: Boudreau et al. (2009): Single-leg exercise variations
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Step-up provides concentric-only option with adjustable range of motion. Reduces balance demands while maintaining unilateral strengthening benefits.
relationships.clinical_application: Learning single-leg strength, knee pain during eccentric loading, balance limitations
relationships.notes: Focus on driving through heel of stepping leg, minimal push from trailing leg

relationships.source_research: Ekstrom et al. (2007): Core muscle activation during exercises
relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Knee support reduces lever arm length, decreasing torque demand by 50%. Maintains similar muscle activation patterns with reduced load.
relationships.clinical_application: Insufficient core strength, lower back pain, learning plank mechanics
relationships.notes: Maintain neutral spine alignment in both variations

relationships.biomechanical_rationale: Isolation exercise allows focus on triceps without shoulder stability demands. Machine assistance enables load progression in smaller increments.
relationships.clinical_application: Insufficient strength for bodyweight dips, shoulder impingement, learning tricep mechanics
relationships.notes: Progress from pushdowns to assisted dips before full bodyweight dips
